sentence: A rebounding housing market has bolstered business at home-improvement retailer Lowe's, which just reported another solid quarter of financial growth.
The expectation of continued strength in the housing market should help the company continue to perform well, analysts say.
Robust sales of both existing and new homes -- bolstered in part by an improving job market -- translate into greater demand for the myriad home and outdoor products thatLowe's ( LOW ) sells.
Before people sell houses, they typically make improvements to attract buyers.
Buyers in turn often invest in new accessories or upgrades to customize or enhance their new homes.
Greater activity on these fronts leads to heavier foot traffic for Lowe's and its competitors, including larger rivalHome Depot ( HD ).
"There's no doubt that when more people put money into that big asset -- their home -- that bodes well for Lowe's and these kinds of retailers," said Mike Matousek, a U.S.
Global Investors trader whose firm invests in home-improvement retailers.
"It's right in their sweet spot."

Lowe's operates more than 1,800 home improvement and hardware stores across North America, most of which are in the U.S.

On Wednesday, the company posted earnings of 80 cents a share for its fiscal third quarter, which ended in October.
It was up 36% from the previous year and two cents above consensus analyst views; it was the 10th straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth.
Revenue climbed 5% to $14.4 billion, in line with estimates.
Same-store sales increased 4.6%.
Lowe's officials would not comment for this article due to a quiet period ahead of its earnings release.

In a statement accompanying the Q3 results, CEO Robert Niblock said that same-store sales growth "was driven by gains in both transactions and average ticket, while our focus on productivity and profitability also allowed us to deliver strong earnings per share growth."
Before the earnings report, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Lowe's full-year earnings to rise 22% in fiscal 2016 and another 20% in fiscal 2017.
The company's stock price trades near 73 and is up about 10% since late September.
One recent growth driver for Lowe's has been the improving U.S. job market.
U.S. employers expanded nonfarm payrolls by 271,000 jobs in October -- the greatest monthly advance of the year.
At the same time, interest rates remain near historic lows, keeping mortgages affordable.
Against that backdrop, the national housing market is advancing.
Existing-home sales rose 4.7% in September -- the most recent month with available data -- to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.55 million, according to the National Association of Realtors.
It nearly matched the level reached in July, when the sales rate hit a post-recession high.

In announcing the latest data, NAR Chief Economist Lawrence Yun cited "an increasing share of pent-up sellers realizing the increased equity they've gained from rising home prices and using it towards trading up or moving into a smaller home."
The latest S&P/Case-Shiller U.S. national home price index increased 4.7% year-over-year in August.
New-home sales, which often swing significantly from month to month, fell from August to September, according to the latest Commerce Department data.
But through the first nine months of 2015, new-home sales, not seasonally adjusted, were up 17.6% from the same period a year earlier.
"My inclination is that the housing sector is going to continue to extend its gains," Ken Mayland, president of ClearView Economics, said in an interview.
As the job market advances, he said, more young Americans are gaining full-time employment, which means that many are moving out of their apartments or parents' homes and looking to buy houses.
"There is now increased interest among more young people to get out of shared residence situations," Mayland said.
"That's very good for the housing market going forward."
It's also a big positive for retailers whose sales are linked to the health of housing.
UBS analyst Michael Lasser noted in an October report that Lowe's can generate even more sales growth in big-ticket categories such as cabinets and new flooring.
Consumer purchases on this front are still 50% below the peak levels touched prior to the recession.
What's more, Lasser noted, Lowe's is actively melding its online sales with in-store customer activity in an effort to drive up volume on both fronts.
Based on recent conversations with management, Lasser said that customers pick up about 60% of online orders at Lowe's stores.
This system allows customers to shop online but get their products faster than they would if they waited for them to be shipped.
Importantly, it increases customers' visits to physical stores, where they often shop further.
At a conference in September, Lowe's Chief Merchandising Officer Mike McDermott said that the company is also working to attract more professional home remodelers and builders.
During the first half of 2015, these customers accounted for about 30% of the chain's business.
To increase that percentage, Lowe's has added more brands for everything from insulation products to roofing materials.
It also has added depth to its inventories, enabling stores to quickly meet larger orders.

"Part of serving the pro is being able to deliver an inventory position that they can leverage as their own warehouse -- a one-stop shop, if you will, so that they can improve their own productivity and bottom line," McDermott said.
As McDermott acknowledged, competition is fierce in the home-improvement space, as it is in most corners of retail.
Home Depot, for one, is busy expanding its product lines and trying to broaden its customer base.
Home Depot is roughly 20% larger than Lowe's in number of stores.
Lowe's also competes against big-box chains such asWal-Mart ( WMT ) in categories such as small appliances and garden equipment, as well as against home furnishing stores.
Meanwhile, one potential headwind to the housing market is the prospect of higher interest rates.
The Federal Reserve is debating whether to begin boosting interest rates as soon as December.
If rates were to climb quickly in 2016, many would-be homebuyers might get spooked by the higher cost of mortgages, resulting in slowing sales.
On the other hand, a Fed decision not to raise rates by early 2016 would likely follow new evidence of economic weakness, Mayland said.
A tepid economy could weigh on home sales, too.
For now, most economists look for continued economic expansion and only a gradual rise in interest rates next year.
Such conditions should allow for continued positive momentum in housing, Mayland said.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
